prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Factors in Deciding Whether Transfer Is Appropriate

para.paratext: The Panel may consider the timing of other events in the litigation in determining when to consider a transfer motion or when to issue a decision on it. The reasons for the Panel's considering the timing of action by it are myriad. Some of the reasons are never articulated by the Panel. Clearly the Panel can act very promptly on motions for transfer, and has done so in cases where the issues appear pressing.[1] The promptness or delay in issuing decisions is never overtly discussed either in the decisions or in subsequent opinions. The Panel has not had any noted breaches of confidentiality of its staff, so there appears to be little material from which to speculate on specific timing decisions of the Panel in using its decisions.[2]

The Panel has stated in its decisions, however, reasons for delaying hearings on transfer motions. The Panel has stayed proceedings before it indefinitely until certain class action determinations could be free of appellate review, whether by appeal or writ.[3] The Panel has also refrained from deciding the question of transfer as to one defendant until the court of appeals could consider an appeal from a consolidation order entered by the transferor court.[4] The Panel ordered transfer of the claims against that party as soon as the court of appeals ruled.[5] In another case the Panel determined, after the hearing on a motion to transfer, to stay Panel action while the parties continued in settlement discussions.[6] The stay was of limited duration, and the Panel then ordered transfer of the non-settled cases for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.[7] The Panel has also stayed transfer of a single action until a pending motion to dismiss could be decided in the transferor court.[8] The Panel has similarly stayed its decision on transfer pending appeal in one of the underlying actions.[9]

The Panel has also rejected a request that it postpone a decision on transfer until the transferor court could determine a motion to remand a matter to state court.[10] That decision is consistent with the Panel's general practice of deferring to the transferee court on such matters. The Panel's presumptive response to the pendency of motions is to order transfer and point out that the motions can be decided by the transferee court after transfer.[11]

In one mass disaster case the Panel declined to order transfer because only a few of an inevitably larger number of actions had been filed, and the Panel determined that it was premature to decide the transfer question and to select a transferee district. The Panel did make it clear, however, that its decision did not foreclose a later motion to transfer.[12] In another massive disaster case, however, the Panel ordered transfer after only a few of the expected thousands of cases had been filed.[13]

The Panel has also delayed decision on transfer motions under 28 U.S.C.A. § 1407 to transfer for pretrial proceedings in order to permit the courts in which the actions are then pending to determine motions for transfer under 28 U.S.C.A. § 1404(a) for all purposes.[14] This practice is not uniform, however, and the Panel has refused to delay its decision on this ground.[15] The Panel has generally declined to delay its decision on the transfer question until the transferor court could rule on a pending motion. In one case the Panel declined to postpone its decision until the transferor court could decide a motion to remand to state court seven tag-along actions removed to federal court.[16] By a stronger argument, the pendency of multiple motions for transfer under § 1404(a) militates strongly towards transfer.[17] The pendency of summary judgment motions or other dispositive motions in a transferor court will not generally result in postponement of a transfer hearing or decision, however.[18]
The Panel has similarly stayed decision on the transfer question until an administrative agency could consider a request for relief similar to that sought in the civil actions.[19]
The Panel ruled in 1975 that the automatic stay provisions of the bankruptcy laws[20] do not prevent it from ordering transfer of multidistrict litigation.[21] The Panel stated in that case:

Transfer of these actions under Section 1407 in no way affects the operation of Bankruptcy Rule 401. We are simply indicating the place where the pretrial proceedings of these actions will occur. The question of the effect of the bankruptcy stay and any modification thereof is entirely a problem to be worked out by the transferee court, the bankruptcy court and the parties. A Section 1407 transfer will produce the salutary consequence of having a single judge coordinate these actions with the bankruptcy proceedings and thereby eliminate the possibility of inconsistent rulings.[22]

As a general rule, however, the Panel does not hold up a ruling on a motion for transfer because of the expected or possible development in either the transferee or transferor court. The Panel has, for example, refused to delay a decision on transfer to permit a party to seek summary judgment in the transferor court.[23] The Panel has also determined that, in addition to having the power to transfer cases to permit the transferee judge to determine motions challenging personal and subject-matter jurisdiction,[24] it would exercise that power in the ordinary case.[25]

Clearly the Panel has a general preference not to delay transfer because of the pendency of a pretrial motion in the transferor court. In some cases, the pendency of such a motion may give the transfer motion increased urgency since transfer would give the opportunity to expand the effect of a pretrial ruling. In one group of patent cases the Panel considered the fact that a summary judgment motion was pending in one court and that such a motion was not ripe in any of the other actions. This fact thus affected both the timing and the selection of a transferee district.[26] Where a motion is pending in one of many closely related cases, the Panel's reaction is not to delay transfer, but to order it, for the single motion can be given effect in multiple actions. In one case the Panel stated:

We see no reason for delaying our decision. The New York and New Jersey actions are completely subsumed in the District of Columbia action and, a fortiori, common questions of fact exist among them. Transfer under Section 1407 will ensure the prevention of duplicative discovery, regardless of the outcome of the dismissal motions and any subsequent maneuvering by the parties. Moreover, the institution of coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings at this time will allow a single judge to consider all three actions and will thereby conserve judicial effort and prevent inconsistent rulings.[27]

The number of actions pending may affect the Panel's decision regarding timing. The Panel has declined to delay transfer in view of the fact that only five of many anticipated actions from a single disaster had been filed.[28] The Panel did note that early transfer would facilitate the handling of later cases that it anticipated. The Panel determined that sufficient facts about the probable litigation had developed to permit it to select an appropriate transferee district.[29] A defendant once sought to delay transfer so that separate class action certification motions could be decided in six different potential transferor courts.[30] The Panel has traditionally viewed multiple, potentially conflicting, class actions as a factor strongly favoring transfer,[31] and followed that policy in this case.[32]

The Panel has delayed transfer where a pending motion relates directly to the Panel's decision. In one case a motion to retransfer a case pursuant to 28 U.S.C.A. § 1404(a) was pending in the transferor court and all parties agreed to exclude that case from the Panel's consideration.[33] The Panel accepted this stipulation, but indicated that it might treat the action as a tag-along action if the retransfer motion were denied by the transferor court.
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
See, e.g., In re Union Carbide Corp. Gas Plant Disaster at Bhopal, India in Dec., 1984, 601 F. Supp. 1035 (J.P.M.L. 1985).

There has not, for example, been any discussion in the press or public disclosures from the law clerks of the members of the Panel. Cf. Robert Woodward & Scott Armstrong, The Brethren (1979) (United States Supreme Court Justices' law clerks quoted at length on confidential matters).
In re Concrete Pipe, 302 F. Supp. 244, 249 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
In re Nat. Student Marketing Litigation, 368 F. Supp. 1311, 1318 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
In re National Student Marketing Litigation, 358 F. Supp. 1303 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
In re Admission Tickets, 302 F. Supp. 1339, 1340 (J.P.M.L. 1969).

See In re Kaehni Patent, 311 F. Supp. 1342, 1344 (J.P.M.L. 1970). See also In re Medtronic, Inc., Implantable Defibrillators Products Liability Litigation, 408 F. Supp. 2d 1351 (J.P.M.L. 2005) (transfer ordered for all actions except for one, pending decision on motion to be decided shortly).
See In re Motor Vehicle Air Pollution Control Equipment, 311 F. Supp. 1349 (J.P.M.L. 1970).

See In re Franklin National Bank Securities Litigation, 393 F. Supp. 1093, 1095 (J.P.M.L. 1975). See also In re American Home Mortg. Securities Litigation, 528 F. Supp. 2d 1376 (J.P.M.L. 2007); In re Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Securities Litigation, 429 F. Supp. 2d 1376 (J.P.M.L. 2006) (Panel declines to defer decision on motion for transfer despite pending motion before transferor court).
See, e.g., People of New York v. Guidant Corp, 2006 WL 1984688 (J.P.M.L. 2006).
See In re Air Crash Disaster at Anchorage, Alaska on November 27, 1970, 342 F. Supp. 755, 756 (J.P.M.L. 1972). The finality of Panel decisions on transfer is discussed in greater detail in § 5:59.
See In re Union Carbide Corp. Gas Plant Disaster at Bhopal, India in Dec., 1984, 601 F. Supp. 1035 (J.P.M.L. 1985).
In re Deering Milliken Patent, 328 F. Supp. 504 (J.P.M.L. 1970); see also In re Oxycontin Antitrust Litigation, 314 F. Supp. 2d 1388 (J.P.M.L. 2004).

See In re H & R Block, Inc., Express IRA Marketing Litigation, 444 F. Supp. 2d 1339 (J.P.M.L. 2006); In re Trade Secrets in Mfg. High Molecular Weight Polyethylene, 339 F. Supp. 1276, 1277 n.2 (J.P.M.L. 1972). The Panel's treatment of motions under section 1404(a) generally is discussed in § 5:49.
See In re Air Crash Disaster at Juneau, Alaska, on September 4, 1971, 360 F. Supp. 1406, 1407 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
See In re Union Pacific Railroad Co. Employment Practices Litigation, 314 F. Supp. 2d 1383 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
In re Zyprexa Products Liability Litigation, 314 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2004); see In re Ivy, 901 F.2d 7 (2d Cir. 1990).
See In re Air Fare Litigation, 322 F. Supp. 1013, 1015 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
See In re Franklin National Bank Securities Litigation, 393 F. Supp. 1093, 1095 (J.P.M.L. 1975).

See In re Holiday Magic Securities and Antitrust Litigation, 368 F. Supp. 806, 807 (J.P.M.L. 1973). Accord In re Data General Corp. Antitrust Litigation, 510 F. Supp. 1220, 1227 (J.P.M.L. 1979) (transfer not delayed for pending motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim); In re Cement and Concrete Antitrust Litigation, 465 F. Supp. 1299, 1301 (J.P.M.L. 1979) (same).
The power of the Panel to transfer actions regardless of the pendency of motions to dismiss for lack of jurisdiction in the transferor court is discussed in § 5:40.
The Panel's willingness to have the transferee court decide pretrial motions is discussed in Chapter 9.
See In re Molinaro/Catanzaro Patent Litigation, 380 F. Supp. 794, 795 (J.P.M.L. 1974). The possible role of this factor in selection of a transferee district is discussed in §§ 5:27 and 6:21.
See In re Griseofulvin Antitrust Litigation, 395 F. Supp. 1402, 1403 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
See In re Air Crash Disaster Near Saigon, South Vietnam, on April 4, 1975, 404 F. Supp. 478, 479 (J.P.M.L. 1975).

See In re Piper Aircraft Distribution System Antitrust Litigation, 405 F. Supp. 1402, 1403 (J.P.M.L. 1975). Accord In re Bristol Bay, Alaska, Salmon Fishery Antitrust Litigation, 424 F. Supp. 504, 507 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
The role of conflicting class actions as a factor favoring transfer is discussed in § 5:24.
See In re Cenco Inc. Securities Litigation, 434 F. Supp. 1237, 1237–1238 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
